person.note: James Lovell Proctor (1833-1910), Anglican clergyman from Yorkshire who served with the Universities\' Mission to Central Africa (UMCA) 1861-63. He was one of Bishop Mackenzie\'s original party who succeeded him as head of the Mission.
Lorenzo Johnson (dates as yet unidentified), a Jamaican cook who travelled to Africa with Bishop Mackenzie.
Reverend Henry Carter Scudamore (?-1863) arrived with Bishop Mackenzie aboard the Pioneer. He died from fever in 1863.

Senhor Vianna, sometimes Vienna, (dates as yet unidentified), a planter and slaver who gave much assistance to the Zambesi Expedition. \'Vianna\'s\' is marked on Livingstone\'s map of the area in his Shire Journal 1861-1864. It was at the junction of the Mutu and the Zambesi rivers.
Tito Augusto d\'Araujo Sicard (?-1864), Portuguese Commandant of Tete up to 1859. From 1862-64 he was Commandant of Mazaro and the Shire. He was also the temporary Governor of Quilimane.

Senhor Vianna, sometimes Vienna, (dates as yet unidentified), a planter and slaver who gave much assistance to the Zambesi Expedition. \'Vianna\'s\' is marked on Livingstone\'s map of the area in his Shire Journal 1861-1864. It was at the junction of the Mutu and the Zambesi rivers.
Lorenzo Johnson (dates as yet unidentified), a Jamaican cook who travelled to Africa with Bishop Mackenzie.
Abraham Pearce (?-1863), Quartermaster on the Ariel, which arrived in the Zambesi in July 1862. He died in Quilimane, 4 June 1863.

Possibly Gualdino José Nuñes (dates as yet unidentified), Military Commandant of Quilimane, who occasionally handled Livingstone\'s financial transactions. He was acting Governor of the district until 1857.
Mariano (dates as yet unidentified), a slave-trader on the River Shire. Livingstone mentions Marianno [sic] as one of the causes of depopulation of the lower Shire valley in a letter of 1863.

place.note: Elephant Swamp was a vast marsh, "Nyanja Mukulu", on the River Shire, frequented by large herds of elephants.

div.p:
Johnston brings
the most distressing
intelligence of the
death of our
beloved Scudamore
I feel like JacobJoseph's
bretheren "What
shall we say or
what shall we
speak" It is the
Lord & yet it is
shall I say terrible
It seems as if here
we are to be tried
as much as they
were in the west
may equal success
follow. May the
Almighty comfort
you.

Will you take
charge of a canoe
for us with
100 panjas of
rice from Vianna
or of mantiments
not beans - which
I write for. If
SrTito is at
mouth of Shire
and hear what
he says about
some rice I have
asked from him
I am doubtful
of Vianna now
since he deceiveddeceived
us once. I advised
Johnstone to go
on & help you
as he had come
so far. We have
met a new bank
here. We came up
quickly to this &
now have lost
a couple of days
but will soon get
on. We are all
well thank God
except Pearce who
has been long down
but is recovering

the Commandante of
the mouth of the
Shire told us that
a canoe was
seized by him
with arms ammu-
nition. Wines
spirits &c For

up in name
